questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Drag and drop the code from the bottom onto the box where the code is missing to provision several new Cisco UCS servers simultaneously by using the UCS XML API. Options may be used more than once. Not all options are used.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Given answer is correct. 

The question refers to "new" servers which means the method would be POST (to create) rather than PUT (to update). 

Also "lsDeployNTemplate" isn't an option within the API at all. Look at the "lsInstantiateNTemplate" section in this documentation and you can see an almost identical payload to that provided in the answer:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/unified_computing/ucs/sw/api/UCSM_API_Guide/b_UCSM_API_Guide_3_1_chapter_011.html

questions.question_text: How is client code that consumes gRPC telemetry implemented, assuming that the preferred language is able to be chosen?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I asked ChatGPT.
B. Compile the protocol buffers IDL.
How confident are you in your answer?
I am highly confident in my answer as gRPC uses Protocol Buffers as the Interface Definition Language (IDL) to define the schema of the service and data types. The Protocol Buffers IDL is used to generate client and server code in multiple languages including C++, C#, Go, Java, JavaScript, Objective-C, PHP, Python, Ruby, Dart, and more. The other options you've listed are not related to gRPC or Protocol Buffers.

choices.A: Leverage a Thrift code generator to parse a Thrift IDL.
choices.C: Review the Swagger API documentation to build client code.

choices.D: Leverage middleware caching and respond with HTTP code 204 in the API response.
choices.C: Include the “ETag” header in the API response.
choices.B: Include the “Last-Modified” header in the API response.
choices.E: Leverage middleware caching and respond with HTTP code 104 in the API response.
choices.A: Include the “Content-Type” header in the API response.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An application hosting server in the local data center is experiencing large amounts of traffic from end-users. A developer must optimize this API server to reduce the load on its host. What are two ways to optimize this code through HTTP cache controls? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
I would go for B and C.
B and C are the answers because these headers allow the API server to send cached versions of responses in the event that the content of the response has not changed since the last time it was requested. This reduces the load on the server by avoiding the need to recreate the response for every request.

Selected Answer: BC
Agree with B and C. Correction from my friend.

B: last modified
D: 204 only returns headers, so reduce traffic if nothing has changed

choices.C: Use the Cisco IOxClient tool to export the application to a ZIP file and push the file to the switch.
choices.D: Copy the application code to a NETCONF file and upload the file to the switch.
choices.A: Export the application as a TAR file and import the file to the switch.
choices.B: Connect the switch to Cisco DNA Center and push the application through the platform.

questions.question_text: A developer creates an application for a Cisco Catalyst 9000 switch in a Docker container. Which action must be taken to host the application on the switch?

discussion.content:
given answer is correct.

Once developers have built the docker application, running the standard “docker save” command can be used to export the application as “.tar” compressed file. The application can then be deployed on the Catalyst 9000 series switches. Cisco’s ioxclient tool is no longer required to package the application. Ioxclient is an optional tool for developers who want to define additional parameters for the application.

Selected Answer: A
Steps are:

1. Design, develop, and dockerize the application.
2. Upload the containerized application to a repository, save the container as a .tar file, and prepare and format the USB drive.
3. Download the application to usbflash1 and configure the relevant VLAN interface on the switch.
4. Install the application on the switch via the CLI
5. Configure the application that hosts vNIC on the switch.
6. Activate and start the hosted application via the CLI

Selected Answer: A
Yes its A

here other link about docker

https://developer.cisco.com/docs/app-hosting/#!getting-started-with-docker-applications-deployment/install-activate-and-start-app
Guys, answer is B, here is the step by step= https://ccie.tv/deploying-docker-containers-to-a-cisco-catalyst-9300/

Selected Answer: A
I'll go on A

Selected Answer: B
From Official Cert Guide "You now have several deployment options. You can use:
Cisco DNA Center, Cisco IOx Local Manager, or you can do CLI-based actions." 
A could assume CLI, B is correct, C is IOx LM, no client tool

Correct answer is A:
Create docker and import to a tar file:
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/app-hosting/#!docker-applications-development/tutorial-build-sample-docker-python-simple-app
Install a tar file after import to Switch flash:
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/app-hosting/#!getting-started-with-docker-applications-deployment/install-activate-and-start-app

According to ChatGPT, C is correct:
Cisco IOx is a platform that allows you to run third-party applications on Cisco switches, routers, and other devices. It enables you to package your application in a Docker container and run it on the device.

To host the application on the switch, you would use the Cisco IOxClient tool to export the application from the Docker container as a ZIP file. The IOxClient tool allows you to create and manage IOx applications on the switch. Once you have the application in a ZIP file, you can then push the file to the switch using IOxClient and run the application on the switch.

comments.content: I'm gonna change my mind to A, since this is the process today.
